Title:
Morphological and genetic characterization of Hericium
erinaceus found in the temperate forests of the Sierra Madre Occidental,
Mexico
Abstract:
This species Hericium erinaceus (Bull.) Pers, known in the
literature as lion’s mane, Bear’s head, Hog’s head fungus and could be
found wild through European countries and North America, meanwhile in
Asia is mostly artificially cultivated. Despite these remarkable
properties, taxonomic and genetic identification inside the genus is
difficult. The use of molecular characters such as rDNA internal
transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences has been helpful for species
delimitations, especially to differentiate Chinese H. erinaceus from
related mushrooms. The objective of this work was to contribute to the
knowledge of Hericium erinaceus in the temperate forests of the Sierra
Madre Occidental (SMO), Mexico, through a morphological and molecular
characterization using rDNA ITS markers, as well as an environmental
characterization where this species thrives. The Study area was in
pineoak forests of Sierra Madre Occidental Pueblo Nuevo, Durango, Mexico
is located at coordinates 23º 5’ to 23°70 N and 105º 21 to 105°57’ W.
The collection of the specimens was carried out in the months from July
to September during two years, 2016 and 2017 and herborized for their
preservation, identified and deposited at the Mycological Herbarium of
the Instituto de Botánica, Universidad de Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico
(IBUG). Isolation of wild strains was carried out using the cloning
technique from living tissue samples. The genomic DNA was extracted
following a CTAB protocol. For the amplification of the ITS rDNA of the
Hericium samples the primers ITS1 (5- TCCGTAGGTGAACCTGCGG-3) and ITS4
